proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we Australians have as a right.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to guarantee the provision of our adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits through local community pharmacies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Privacy Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment;
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Home Ownership
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have rushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Vietnam: End of War List
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the armed forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War, the Australian Government approved an end of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an end of war list at end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government, and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of W/Officer Kevin Conway, Australian Army Training Team Vietnam, be considered for the Award of a Posthumous Military Honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Medicare: Abortions
petition.para: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. With the Industrial Relations Commission shortly to begin a Full Bench hearing on the pilots dispute, what powers has the Commission to enforce any decision that it might make at today's hearing or any subsequent hearing?

—I think that the Commission could probably exercise those powers which are in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but I am not precisely sure of the details. There are a number of powers, as Senator Chaney is well aware. I do not have the legislation here, so I cannot read them to him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not sure whether I wish to thank the Minister for that extraordinary answer, but I remind the Minister that his colleague Mr Willis, who was then the Minister for Industrial Relations, described the provisions, which are the same as those in the current Act, as moribund and made a statement which made it quite clear that he thought the provisions to enforce decisions were ineffectual. I ask the Minister: In view of the importance of this dispute, will he examine the Act and advise the Senate without delay what powers the Commission has to enforce any decision it might make today or, indeed, at any subsequent time?
—Yes, I am quite prepared to do that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is it correct that the Child Support Act provides for collection of maintenance only from the date upon which a court order is registered with the Child Support Agency (CSA)? Will the Government consider introducing further legislation so that arrears accrued under court orders for maintenance, prior to the registration of any order with the Child Support Agency, may be collected and distributed by the Agency?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —Luckily I have an answer from the Minister for Social Security in response to Senator Colston's question. It is true that the Child Support Agency can generally only enforce liabilities to pay maintenance that occur after the date on which an order or agreement is lodged with the Agency. There are two reasons for this. First, when a person fails to pay maintenance due under an order or agreement made under the Family Law Act the arrears of maintenance are enforceable by the courts as a matter of discretion; that is, the amount of the arrears is not automatically a debt due to the person entitled to the maintenance, rather, the person needs to persuade a court under the Family Law Act to make a particular order to enforce the arrears. The Child Support Agency system is very different; one could say it is much tougher. Once a liability is registered with the Agency, any amount not paid on time is automatically a debt due to the Child Support Agency. No question of a court's discretion arises. The Child Support Agency can sue for that debt in any appropriate civil court.

answer.para: That means that if arrears that accrued before registration of the liability with the CSA could be registered with the Agency, the child support legislation would retrospectively alter the legal rights and duties of parents. The Minister has presented an example to show the effect. If a non-custodial parent was ordered 10 years ago to pay $30 a week maintenance but has paid nothing in that time, under the Family Law Act the custodial parent could take proceedings to enforce the arrears of about $15,000 but it would be a matter of discretion for the courts whether that amount would be enforced and how it is enforced. In many cases the court might enforce only about $1,500 of the arrears. If, on the other hand, that $15,000 were a liability to the Child Support Agency there would be no discretion; it would be a firm debt beyond the review of the courts.

The second reason relates to the very practical problem of establishing the amount of any arrears. Before the child support scheme was introduced, one of the most common disputes between separated parents concerned whether maintenance had been paid and whether money that had been paid was for maintenance. For example, when a non-custodial parent paid a phone bill for a custodial parent was the amount paid instead of or additional to a liability to pay weekly maintenance? The only acceptable forum to resolve these sorts of issues is the courts. For these reasons there has been no change at all to the rights of people entitled to arrears that accrue before registration with the Child Support Agency. They can still enforce orders through the courts but must go to the courts to enforce them. Of course, if custodians are in hardship they are free to apply to a court for a variation of their maintenance order which can then be collected by the Child Support Agency.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. Why has the Government done an about-face by supporting today's Industrial Relations Commission hearing to arbitrate on the pilots dispute after weeks of totally rejecting any suggestion of an arbitrated settlement? Does this mean that the Government finally and belatedly accepts, after weeks of abusing the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, that the AFAP may have a role to play in the settlement of this dispute?

—The Air Pilots Federation withdrew from the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government did not ask it to do that. Nobody else did either. It was its own decision. Members of the Air Pilots Federation decided to resign en masse, thereby rendering themselves no longer employees of the airlines. The Government did not do that. With regard to the hearing today, convened by the President of the Industrial Relations Commission, the Federation will have an opportunity to participate today in the settlement of this dispute, if it so wishes. In the Government's view it should take that opportunity. The Government will be intervening in the hearing to put the Government's position.

question.block.title: SENATOR HAINES: NATIONAL PRESS CLUB SPEECH

talk.start.para: —Has the Minister for Finance seen a report in this morning's Australian of a speech by Senator Haines to the National Press Club yesterday in which she proposed increasing subsidies for home buyers and suggested that Australia's tax regime was not high enough? Has the Minister examined Senator Haines's proposals? Has he costed them? What are their costs? Will the Government implement her alternative solutions?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I certainly have seen the report in this morning's Australian. I have not seen the entire speech, and I have not been able, therefore, to do a comprehensive or entirely accurate costing of the figures in the speech. It is a pity that Question Time was not on at 2 o'clock. However, it is clear from the reports that have been published that what Senator Haines is advocating would cost about $10 billion. Senator Haines wants to present herself to the electors of Kingston as Santa Claus handing out goodies-$10 billion worth of Christmas sweets. That is the way Senator Haines wants to be seen by the electors of Kingston, and she hopes she can con them with that.

answer.para: I have another message for the electors of Kingston. To pay for Senator Haines's $10 billion worth of Christmas sweets would require a 20 per cent increase in personal income tax. So let the electors of Kingston remember that if they want Senator Haines's bundle of Christmas goodies, their income tax is going to go up by 20 per cent. They would be paying 20 per cent more tax if Senator Haines's program were to be implemented. To be fair, there is one alternative to that. Senator Haines is purported to have said:
The fact is that whether we are talking about payroll tax, personal tax, indirect tax or whatever, Australia is nowhere near the top of the tax tree.

There is one way in which the 20 per cent increase in personal income tax implicit in her speech can be avoided, and that is by the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax or a value added tax which adds $10 billion to present indirect tax collections. I look forward to Senator Haines clarifying whether she intends to break with 12 years, I think, of alleged Democrat tradition in opposing not only broad-based consumption taxes but any increase in indirect taxes at all, or whether she proposes to put up personal income tax by 20 per cent and make every elector in Kingston pay 20 per cent more income tax than is the case now.

talk.start.para: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance and bears very much on high interest rates and a number of other problems in our community. I note that the morning after the announcement of last month's balance of trace deficit figures the Adelaide press carried advertisements for French brandy bottled in France. Noting that over 20 per cent of that deficit was related to imports of food, beverages and textiles, all things made in adequate amounts and quantity in Australia, is the Government still blindly committed to the ideology of deregulation and open markets? Would it not be more appropriate and beneficial simply to control these unnecessary imports?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I am sceptical, to say the least, as to whether food, beverages and textiles comprise 20 per cent of our total imports. Senator Button has just told me that food accounts for $100m, which would be something like 0.25 per cent of our total imports, and that consumption goods, including food, beverages and textiles, although textiles are not necessarily consumer goods, comprise about 25 per cent in total of our imports. However, leaving that reservation aside, the idea that Senator Coulter has put up has a good deal of superficial appeal. That is why one hears it from people other than Senator Coulter.

answer.para: We have a worrying current account deficit. `Ipso facto', the superficial argument goes, `let us restrict imports, as this is a painless way of dealing with the problem'. There are many flaws in that superficially appealing argument. The first one, of course, is that imports are a component of consumption; therefore, if imports are cut off, consumption falls, other things remaining equal. So it is not painless on that front. There are other technical and political problems. The political problem, of course, is that if barriers to imports are raised there is the possibility, the danger, that there will be retaliatory action by other countries against Australian exports. On the technical problems, if quantitative barriers to imports were to be introduced there would be a lead time for their introduction of, I understand, about six months. In that six-month period the message would go out to everybody that if they want to import particular goods they should make sure that they do so within the next six months because quantitative restrictions will come in. Everybody would know that six months hence they would not be able to buy French brandy, to take Senator Coulter's example. What do honourable senators think the response to that would be?

talk.start.para: —Shock, horror!

—There would be an import surge of French brandy. Senator Richardson could make sure that his drinks cupboard was not without French brandy. He would not be the only one to go out to buy a big heap of French brandy before the import restrictions came in.

answer.para: One other alternative-I do not want to spend much more time on this-is that we could impose higher duties. That could be done more quickly-indeed, it could be done almost overnight. That would have the same effect as a change in the exchange rate. We had a major depreciation of the Australian dollar in 1986. Depending on whether one measures it against the United States dollar or the trade weighted index, within a period of 12 months there was a depreciation of the order of 30 per cent. It may even have been a little higher. While presumably that had some impact on imports, it did not have the dramatic impact on imports that many people would have expected.

question.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am very interested to learn that Senator Richardson, and presumably other members of the Government, would prefer to consume French brandy rather than Australian brandy at a time when we have a high trade deficit. If I could just correct Senator Walsh, the figures given in relation to the deficit clearly indicate that 20 per cent of our trade deficit was related to those imports. But the question remains: to what extent are these unnecessary imports consumed by the well-to-do?

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —In my view, those who drink French brandy are the well-to-do. Certainly we, on this side of the chamber, do not drink French brandy. To what extent are the poor paying for the high interest rates and other penalties arising from the ideology of this Government which is committed to a policy of open imports without restriction so that it can satisfy the unnecessary frivolities of its rich mates?
—I call Senator Walsh. I think there is a supplementary question in there somewhere.

—I must confess that, like you, Mr President, I had some trouble finding it and I am not sure that I succeeded even then. Lest I be misunderstood in mentioning Senator Richardson, he just happened to be the person sitting near me at the time I was speaking. Frankly, I do not know whether Senator Richardson drinks French brandy. However, some French brandy is very expensive. I think it is called cognac-I do not know much about it either. There is also some French brandy which, I understand, is very cheap and which could probably be more accurately described as rotgut. So French brandy is not necessarily expensive. I am trying to think what the supplementary question was. Like you, Mr President, I am having difficulty. The question seems to be based on an assumption that imports are more than proportionately consumed by high income groups. While commonsense tells one that that is true for, say, Mercedes Benz, BMW or Rolls Royce cars, I am aware of absolutely no evidence which demonstrates that imports in total are consumed or bought more than proportionately by high income groups.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen the reported prediction of United States Senator Al Gore that the United States Congress will reject the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities? Do Senator Gore's comments represent a fillip to Australian and French attempts to win wide support for a comprehensive environmental protection agreement that would prevent mining of any sort in Antarctica?

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —Yes, I have seen the news from the very influential United States senator, Senator Gore, predicting the demise of the Antarctic minerals convention in the United States Senate and also urging the United States Administration to follow the Australian example, set aside the Convention and work instead for a new international agreement that would preserve the magnificent Antarctic wilderness intact. Certainly, we take the view that Senator Gore's very public intervention in this matter will give a significant fillip to the Australian initiative. That initiative commenced in May this year with the Prime Minister's announcement that Australia would not sign the Antarctic minerals convention, but instead would pursue the urgent negotiation of a comprehensive environmental protection convention within the framework of the Antarctic Treaty system. The objectives in doing that, and also at the same time seeking to strengthen and extend the present moratorium on minerals activity in Antarctica, were taken up by the Prime Minister and me with the Antarctic Treaty countries that we both visited in June and in the course of subsequent international meetings that we have attended. The governments of India, France and Belgium publicly supported the Australian initiative and sympathetic responses have been received from Sweden, Italy, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Federal Republic of Germany, Poland and a number of non-consultative parties to the Antarctic Treaty. We have also received favourable hearings from a number of Latin American and other consultative and non-consultative parties.

answer.para: On 18 August the Australian and French Prime Ministers here in Canberra announced that Australia and France would propose jointly that the Treaty parties negotiate a comprehensive environmental protection convention to turn the Antarctic into a wilderness reserve. Since that joint statement a number of approaches have been jointly made at official levels within the various countries that are being targeted in this initiative seeking support for that approach. Now the joint initiative will be considered at the next meeting of Antarctic Treaty consultative parties in Paris, which is to take place in October, just next month. At that meeting we will seek support for a special consultative meeting next year committed to develop urgently a comprehensive environmental protection regime.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. As the dispute which has disrupted Australia's domestic air flights continues, there have been reports of incidents related to air safety, particularly in regard to the greater use of smaller aircraft. First, what extra action is being taken by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to check maintenance of small planes? Secondly, have there been inspections to ensure that pilots flying smaller planes are not exceeding their allocated flying hours? Thirdly, as pilots are being required to fly unfamiliar aircraft to unfamiliar locations, can the Minister indicate what air safety incidents have occurred and whether they involved small aircraft and/or overseas and management pilots who have been recruited to provide domestic flights?

—I have already commented at great length in recent days on the measures that the Civil Aviation Authority has been taking to ensure that no question of safety arises in the context of foreign pilots coming into this country. That is also true in relation to foreign aircraft coming here. The fact is that the CAA will not authorise any operation in Australia until it is completely satisfied about the safety of that operation. As to the implications of the dispute for the conduct of general aviation and smaller aircraft to which Senator Panizza refers, I will have to take that question on notice. I will try to get him an answer before the end of the week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and concerns the figures on living costs and housing affordability released yesterday. I draw the Minister's attention to three key features of these figures: the average weekly household expenditure on food, housing and living costs is actually higher than average weekly ordinary time earnings for full-time adults; low income families spend proportionately more on basic living costs; and average repayments on new home loans reached 35.8 per cent of average family income in the June quarter. Does the Minister agree that his Government's economic policies are making it harder for families to exercise true freedom of choice by, first, trying to exist on one income and, secondly, commencing and raising a family? I and, I am sure, many hundreds of thousands of Australian families would like to know whether it is now an unannounced Government policy that Australian families should be persuaded into adopting a two-income situation where the mother is forced into the paid work force despite her desire to be a full time home-maker, particularly whilst her children are still young? Is it also a hidden policy of the Government that not just newly married couples but even perhaps those who have been married for several years should be forced by economic circumstances to choose between adequate housing and the commencement of a family? If these outcomes are not supported by the Government will the Minister say so unequivocally?

—The early part of the question relates to results of some survey material and so on. I do not have that information with me and so cannot comment on that part of the question. I will obtain an answer about that as soon as I can. The burden of the second part of the question is whether there is an unannounced policy of the Government that women should be in the position where they have to work and that the Government in some sinister way is using economic policy to influence social behaviour and social attitudes. There is no such unannounced policy and it is not the intention of the Government that that should happen. It is clearly the intention of the Government-and it has been from the beginning-that we in this country should be in a situation of as near full employment as is possible and in a situation which provides opportunities and choices for women and others either in or potentially in the work force. That has resulted in high participation rates in employment during this Government's period of office. Indeed, the trend towards higher participation rates in the work force increased over a number of years before this Government came to office as well as under this Government. All that means is that there are changing social patterns and changing opportunities. That is all the Government would wish to see-that there should be choice and opportunity available to everyone in terms of employment if they desire to take it.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question because my question did not relate to the question of choice in the work force. Obviously I have been involved in that too. My question related to whether there is an underlying assumption now that two incomes are required in order for the average household to make ends meet.
—No, there is no such underlying assumption and there is no evidence to support that assumption.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I presume that the Minister and the Treasurer are aware that section 23 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 specifically prohibits the provision of financial assistance for industry for a period of more than two years except in certain defined circumstances, which do not apply to the provision of financial assistance decided on by the Government to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. Why is the Government acting unlawfully in breach of the clear provisions of the IAC Act in its decision to provide assistance to Kodak (Australasia) over a period of five years?

—I know that section 23 of the IAC Act says something like what Senator Lewis claims it does, but his assertions of unlawful acts are without foundation. If the Government proceeds with this-and Senator Button has just confirmed this-it will be by way of legislation and, therefore, the legislation will override section 23 of the IAC Act.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of the outrageous situation whereby consumers who pay their telephone or gas bills by Bankcard at bank branches have those payments treated as cash advances rather than normal Bankcard transactions? Does the Minister agree that consumers are being unfairly disadvantaged by this practice?

answer.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talk.start.para: —I believe that both Telecom Australia and the Australian Gas Light Company (AGL) have entered into an arrangement with two banks-the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Westpac Banking Corporation-to allow accounts to be paid at bank branches. Of course, this does not deny consumers the right to pay those accounts directly in the normal way by cash or cheque to both Telecom and AGL, but it does allow for payments to be made by cash, cheque or Bankcard at branches of those two banking institutions. I am also advised that if the consumer pays by way of a Bankcard, either by telephone or by the account being returned by mail, those transactions are treated as normal Bankcard transactions. However, if a consumer goes to a bank branch and pays the account with a Bankcard I am advised that those transactions are treated as cash advances and, accordingly, attract interest immediately.

answer.para: This seems to be quite a confusing situation. It is inconsistent and, obviously, by its capacity to mislead people, will make consumers worse off because of the lack of a clear, consistent policy as to the way in which people are charged. As far as the Government is concerned, these sorts of transactions should be treated as transactions and not cash advances, and accordingly, consumers should be billed as such. Because of its capacity to mislead, and the fact that consumers will be disadvantaged by this practice, I am glad to take this opportunity to warn consumers about it. I also indicate that I will be writing to both banking institutions, as well as to the Telecom consumers council, to ask them to rectify the situation in order to remove this inconsistent practice and give consumers clear information so that they are not misled and are not worse off in the way in which they now are.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister confirm that the Government has a policy of keeping interest rates high to reduce the level of domestic demand in the economy? Has the Minister noted yesterday's home affordability survey, as reported in the Australian Financial Review today, which dramatically illustrates the crisis facing Australian home buyers, with record interest rates making it more difficult now than at any time in the last 10 years for people to buy or pay off their homes? With major banks likely to announce further rises in home mortgage rates over the next few weeks, when can Australians, suffering because of the Government's failed economic policies, realistically expect any relief from these crippling interest rates?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —It has been said on a number of occasions that the Government has kept monetary policy tight, as it has fiscal policy and, to a large extent, wages policy, in order to deal with the present economic circumstances with which this country is confronted.

answer.para: The Government does not want to see interest rates remain high, particularly mortgage interest rates, any longer than is required to reduce the current level of imports. Current demand and consumption have been very high. Senator Bjelke-Petersen full well knows that. The alternatives to the current policies, which may produce a better result for new home owners, are policies which will see a dramatic rise in unemployment in this country. The Government does not want to see that. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I hope, would not want to see that either. We do not wish to keep interest rates high any longer than is necessary to achieve that purpose.

I know that the housing industry has done an affordability survey and it is not inconsistent with the current high level of mortgage interest rates. The Government expected that. The housing industry has been in a situation of very high demand and very high production. It is essential that that high level of demand be reduced in order to try to deal with those problems. I am not able to comment on the details of the affordability survey, but as soon as possible we will revert to a situation where housing is more affordable than it is now.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer aware of arguments put forward recently by a Mr John Elliott to the effect that the exchange rate of the Australian dollar should be pushed lower? Does the Minister accept the logic of Mr Elliott's argument and will the Government be acting on it?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I do know that Mr Elliott has recently been complaining about the foreign exchange rate and arguing that the value of the Australian dollar is too high.
—So is Senator Button really.

—But Senator Button is not in the very embarrassing commercial position Mr Elliott finds himself in, in which the Australian foreign exchange rate plays an important part. It relates to the bid by Harlin Holdings for Elders IXL shares, Harlin being a company controlled and owned by Mr Elliott and a number of other Elders executives and directors. Although Mr Elliott tried hard to avoid making a full bid for the other Elders shares, Harlin finally did the right thing and offered $3 for all the Elders IXL shares held by other people and then kept his fingers crossed and hoped that not too many people would accept. But that is not what happened. He misjudged and, according to this morning's Australian Financial Review, Harlin has had to outlay more than $2 billion to pay for the acceptances. Most of the $2 billion-odd appears to have come from overseas and to have the essential features of debt. Therefore, Mr Elliott has had to bring a large volume of money across the foreign exchanges. It follows that, the higher the Australian dollar, the greater the foreign denominated debt required for any given Australian dollar payment, which in this case is a bit over $2 billion. The quantity that Mr Elliott has been required to bring in is so large that in itself it has probably pushed up the rate somewhat. So no wonder he is complaining. But that is his problem.

answer.para: Mr Elliott seems to be saying that the Government ought to intervene in the forex market so that he can carry out transactions at prices that suit his personal purposes. We all know that when he got control of the lever of the Elders IXL till, he pulled it frequently-seven bonus issues in six years. It is like ringing up the jackpot every time. If he ever gets remote control of the levers of government I would hate to think what might happen to Australia.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I think the only formal basis on which I can take a point of order is that the Minister is clearly debating the question. I draw your attention to the fact that the Minister is drawing an extremely long bow in making the point about gains to Mr Elliott if the Australian dollar were lower now, completely omitting any reference to the fact that if the value of the Australian dollar drops, Mr Elliott's liabilities-on the facts that have been put forward by Senator Walsh-will, in fact, be higher and not lower so that it would be to Mr Elliott's personal disadvantage. I simply make that point because the fact that this man is the President of the Liberal Party of Australia means that he is continually subjected to abuse in this chamber with no protection from Standing Orders. Mr President, I think that as President of the Senate you ought to at least ensure that the Minister for Finance does not debate these matters in a way which is a further abuse of the Parliament.

—Order! Could I say to Senator Walsh that the question, as I heard it, was `Will the Government take the advice of Mr Elliott concerning the level of the currency?'. I think you are straying fairly widely away from that question. I would ask you to confine your remarks to it.

—I had actually finished my answer. But I thought it was implicit in what I said that the Government will not be taking advice on the exchange rate from Mr Elliott. As for the technical matters that Senator Chaney raised when he was debating the matter by way of a point of order, I suggest that he read my answer carefully and he will find that the assumption upon which he is basing his debating point is wrong.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to remarks made yesterday by the Treasurer to the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress where he is reported as urging the trade union movement to use the billions of dollars invested in trade union controlled superannuation funds to increase its industrial clout. Does the Minister agree that a consequence of the Government's superannuation policy is to increase the power of union leaders? Will the Minister support the use of superannuation funds by unions, or anyone, to achieve economic, political or industrial objectives as opposed to providing for retirement? Will the Minister confirm that the sole aim of trustees of funds must be to maximise the return on investment of those funds so as to maximise the retirement benefits of the individual participants in the funds? Will he also confirm that this statement by the Treasurer vindicates the concern by many Australians, including members of the Opposition, that occupational superannuation was introduced not for the benefit of wage earners but to enhance the muscle and power of trade union leaders over their own members and the Australian community at large?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —As Question Time is taking place so early I have had a very superficial look at this morning's newspapers. But I have not seen even a report of the Treasurer's remarks yesterday. I can say that the assertion in Senator Parer's last question, when he asked, `Is it true that the Government introduced occupational superannuation not for the benefit of employees but for other reasons?' is wrong. The answer to that, of course, is that the Government did not pursue occupational superannuation for other reasons. The Government has encouraged occupational superannuation for two reasons: firstly, for a contribution to the required higher level of total savings in this country; and, secondly, as a contribution to higher retirement income for the individuals to whom it accrues.

answer.para: This is in marked contrast, if I may say, to the days when superannuation was abused by crooks like the Kelly brothers and all the other operators of cherry picker schemes who made sure that none of their employees ever qualified for superannuation because the trust deed was drawn up in such a way that those employees did not qualify until they were 60 or 65 years of age. The Kelly brothers made certain that none of their employees remained employed with their organisation when they were 60 or 65 years of age. That was just a massive fraud perpetrated against the taxpayers of Australia. That is the sort of fraudulent superannuation policy that Senator Parer's party-Senator Parer was not personally responsible because he was not here-presided over for years and for which Senator Parer and all his fellow Liberal Party of Australia senators, Senator Harradine, and most of the Australian Democrat senators, used their votes in this place. They ensured that crooks like the Kelly brothers got away with that ill-gotten money, the millions that they had stolen from the taxpayers of Australia. Senator Parer should look at his own conscience about that.

I have been asked whether superannuation policy increases the power of union leaders. Frankly, I do not know whether there is any individual case where that may be so, but if there is, it depends on the way in which the superannuation fund is drawn up and the balance of the trustees. The common thing in most funds-I will check this out for Senator Parer if he wishes-is that there is an employee representative on the trust, an employer representative, and one other. On the question of the duties of trustees-again I will check this out-as I understand it, the trustees do have a legal obligation to manage the fund in the interests of the contributors. What is in the interests of the contributors at some point I suppose is likely to become subjective, but the clear intention of the law and the duty of the trustee is to manage the fund in the way that maximises the returns to the contributors.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I agree with the Minister's remarks in respect of abuse of funds, but the question I am really asking is: If the trade union movement follows the advice given to it gratuitously yesterday by the Treasurer, will it not be abusing its position as trustee by using those funds `for its own political and economic influence'?
—I have already said that I have not even seen the newspaper report of the Treasurer's comments yesterday, so I am in no position to respond to that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. In view of the decision by the non-Labor majority of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly to pass legislation to end the fluoridation of Canberra's water supply, can the Minister provide any medical or scientific evidence to justify the decision of the Australian Capital Territory Assembly? Does the Federal Government have any evidence that the Australian Capital Territory Assembly is being influenced by other organisations with similar bizarre ideas, such as the Flat Earth Society and the League of Rights, and by those who believe that the universe was created in seven days?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I am not sure whether I can answer that last question because I cannot see into the minds of the members of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly, but I did notice that the bizarre and misguided decisions of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly to remove fluoridation from the water supply did occur yesterday and that it runs counter to the best available medical and scientific evidence and advice.

answer.para: The very active campaign for the fluoridation of Australia's water supply which is being led by dentists in this country, and in particular the Australian Dental Association, has been one of the major factors in earning Australia the envious reputation of one of the most dentally healthy nations in the world. Indeed, Australia has become a world leader in this area with some 70 per cent of the population using fluoridated water. Without doubt this has proven to be the most effective and economical preventative procedure for the control of dental caries or tooth decay that has yet been discovered. It not only enhances general dental health throughout the community, but also reduces the necessity for dental treatment and, therefore, the associated costs that go along with that.

The difference between generations of Australians in the quality of Australian teeth represents one of the great preventative health achievements in this country in the twentieth century. Indeed, in terms of a measure of community health it means that lower income earners, who in the past faced a high dental bill, have had that cost removed from their shoulders, which is a saving in terms of their disposable income. In that sense it is a major community health reform.

In the last dozen years there has been a massive 60 per cent decline in the incidence of dental caries or tooth decay among children aged between six and 13 years. So great and so rapid has been the progress that Australia's child dental health status now exceeds the World Health Organisation's goal for the year 2000. This represents a massive improvement in child dental health. I am not suggesting that fluoridation is the only factor which has led to these improvements. However, it has been shown to be a major factor. Australian dentists deserve the highest praise for their courageous and unselfish support of the fluoridation campaign. The decision made by the Australian Capital Territory has to be seen as an extraordinarily regressive one in the face of this evidence. As Australia heads towards the 1990s the Australian Capital Territory is going backwards towards the 1950s. It also has to be said that it is an unfair infliction on the people of Queanbeyan, who get their water from the ACT and are now caught by this decision.

There is no evidence whatsoever available in Australia to support claims that fluoride causes medical problems. Indeed, Australia's most prestigious medical and scientific body, the National Health and Medical Research Council, issued a report in 1985 which supported the expansion of the fluoridation program. In its summary, the National Health and Medical Research Council stated:
Examination of scientific literature confirms previous recommendations by Council concerning the safety and effectiveness of fluoridation of water.
It went on to state that the allegations that had been made from time to time about fluoride causing particular medical problems were `not supported by scientific evidence'. It recommended:

The Council noted that while fluoridation of drinking water is widely practised in Australia and other countries, and has been the subject of extensive investigation, there is a significant number of people in Australia who are still being denied the benefits of this well proven public health measure.
The Council reaffirms its previous recommendation concerning fluoridation of water as being a safe and effective measure for control of dental caries.

In answer to Senator Schacht, there is overwhelming medical evidence that it has not only saved the community health bill but also improved the condition of people's health. On that basis the ACT Assembly's decision has to be seen as simply bizarre.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Industrial Relations. —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen an article in this morning's edition of the Age newspaper which claims that Australia's basic science capacity is at risk? Does the Minister agree with this assessment of Australia's basic science capacity?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The Age newspaper article has been drawn to my attention. I must say that it is highly selective and rather misleading as an account of the findings of the Australian Science and Technology Council's recent report on the current state of basic science in Australia which was tabled in the Senate yesterday. In some ways it is a shame that it should be such a selective account because one might have hoped that the report would help to take some of the empty rhetoric out of the so-called science debate. The report entitled Profile of Australian Science, which was prepared by an independent body, endorses the general thrust and direction of the Government's science policies. I recommend that honourable senators obtain a copy of the report and read it.

answer.para: Unlike most recent surveys which focused on the attitudes of small sample groups, the Profile of Australian Science report is based on two years solid empirical research across the entire spectrum of Australian science. It was commissioned by the Government for that purpose. The report debunks the argument often touted by commentators and sometimes members of the Opposition that funding for basic science in Australia is insufficient. Of course, in a sense, it is always insufficient, but there is a question of relativity. The report states:
ASTEC found that overall, the quality of scientific research is adequate for a country with our research population . . .
The financial input to basic research appears to be at about the right level. Its allocation and what it is used for represent difficult problems.

The report goes on to note that spending on basic research over the past six years has grown by 24 per cent in real terms with an annual real growth of 3.65 per cent. It also agrees with the Government's moves to improve the efficiency of the Australian research effort in the method of allocation of funds and so on. The report concludes that a greater proportion of funds should be directed towards Australia's best researchers-I suppose that is a subjective judgment of the Council-who, the report says, are small in number and spread across the country. A number of other issues were raised in the report, but the tone of it and the conclusions which it draws are much more realistic and optimistic than those suggested in the article in this morning's Age.

talk.start.para: —I also address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister noted that those ubiquitous creatures, `official sources', have been at it again; this time telling the Sydney Morning Herald that they did not believe the Minister was `fully behind giving help to Kodak' and that they believed Mr Hawke was the initiator because the plant was in his electorate? Are these helpful sources, who seem very considerate of the Minister's personal standing in this sorry matter, correct in asserting that the memorandum which the Minister confirmed yesterday he had taken to Cabinet was lodged in the Minister's name and prepared by his Department simply for reasons of `propriety'? Will the Minister confirm the `official sources' version that he raised the matter in Cabinet on behalf of, and at the instigation of, the Prime Minister?

—I will not confirm any of that. The point about the answers to yesterday's questions which was clearly not understood by the Opposition was that there is a distinction between bringing forward a submission which makes recommendations to Cabinet and bringing forward a memorandum which canvasses options which might be considered by Cabinet. I brought forward a memorandum. I was responsible for it, and I was a party to the decision which was made. Official sources--
—Senator Evans and all the rest.

—Senator Lewis should not get so excited about this issue. He should be patient. I think that I have answered Senator Puplick's question. I do not propose to comment on `official sources', whoever they may be.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. It may be based on a false premise, namely, the possibility of there being an original idea within the Government. Given that premise, I ask: Whose original idea was it to prepare and submit the memorandum?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —All I am prepared to say about that is that I brought forward the memorandum.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: —It is true. I brought forward the memorandum.
—Hawkey's electorate.

—Oh, just a minute. As I said in answer to questions here yesterday from Senator Patterson, the approach was made by Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd to me. I responded to that approach. No Minister in this Government would have considered the issues any differently if the company had been in John Howard's electorate or anybody else's. I would have taken exactly the same attitude to this issue if the company had been in Darwin or anywhere else. It is nice of honourable senators to make these shonky political suggestions about this issue. I understand that because it is the sort of tradition with which those opposite grew up, if they did grow up. The first question asked by my predecessor in the Liberal Government when people came into his office seeking industry assistance was, `Which electorate is it in?'. Those opposite understand all about that. Industry leaders throughout Australia will tell them that. They will admit that the first question one always asked when seeking industry assistance or tailor-made tariffs, which they got from the Liberal Party during the seven years of the Fraser Government, was, `Which electorate is it in?'. Those opposite understand all that; we do not.

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: —I am sorry to have to delay the Senate when it is about to adjourn for Estimates committees, but I have no choice in view of a newspaper which I have just received a copy of this morning entitled Government Computer News. We have heard Senator Button again in the Senate displaying his ability to be articulate and to use words with special meanings. The situation is that back in May this year his Department advised him to cover up the failure of the partnerships for development program. That advice, given to Senator Button in May, advised him-just note this-that Digital Equipment Corporation Australia Pty Ltd, Bull HN Information Systems and Hewlett-Packard Australia Ltd had failed to reach targets for exports when their efforts were reviewed for the first time and that DEC also failed to reach its research and development expenditure target, whereas six other partners did reach target. The Department gave Senator Button a draft news statement in which it advised him to say:

speech.para: The nine-
that is, the group of them together-
have significantly improved their export performances since entering the program.

That was true in the aggregate but it avoided the fact that three had not improved as much as promised. Let us look at the press release which Senator Button released on 5 July 1989 under the heading `Partnership Companies Exceed Export and R&D Targets'. The first paragraph of this press release stated:

The first nine firms reviewed under the Government's Partnership for Development Program exceeded their combined first year's export targets by four per cent and their combined R&D expenditure estimates by 36 per cent, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, said today.
He then listed the firms:
The firms are Digital Equipment Corporation, Hewlett-Packard, Wang, Cincom Systems, Bull HN, Apollo Domain, Apple, IBM and Unisys.

The truth is that three of those firms did not exceed their first year export targets. Apparently this journalist, Mr Colin Brammall, has got on to this story and discovered that three of those firms did not exceed their targets, but that if they were aggregated the Parliament and the journalists could be misled. I keep warning the Parliament and the journalists: people have to read very carefully between the lines when they read anything that Senator Button has said or written. This is a perfect example. Clearly, he has been caught out in relation to the bribe to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd of $60m over a period of five years. It is unlawful. It is contrary to the Industries Assistance Commission legislation. It is contrary to everything that Senator Button stands for. Indeed, it is contrary to what the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, said when he introduced the Industries Assistance Commission Bill in 1973, when he talked about public disclosure of the reasons why we give assistance to industry.

This Government has not been public in its disclosure of assistance to industry under the partnerships for development program; in fact, it has been very secretive about that. Only as a result of the combined pressure of the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats last year did we manage to force Senator Button to make a statement about that in the Parliament. On 5 July this year-I again go back to his press release-he announced:
The achievement-
honourable senators will note the singular in `the achievement'; not `the achievements'-
by this group of Partners, together accounting for over 85 per cent of this Program, is an early sign that the Partnership for Development Program is working.

Senator Button claims that his program is working when the truth is that one-third of those people have not achieved their requirements. I say once again that Senator Button has been caught out. According to Mr Colin Brammall there was another matter. The article states:

The department also advised Button to make public a mistake by Ditac in negotiating a partnership agreement with Cincom, because it would be embarrassing for the Government if it leaked out. It suggested calling it a `misunderstanding' discovered by the verification process.
The advice was given-
to the Minister-
at the end of May in a confidential minute, with commercial-in-confidence attachments and a draft news statement.
I have already read part of that statement. The article continues:
The confidential advice included that Cincom's partnership targets and performance had had to be downgraded.
Apparently, according to Mr Brammall, this was because of a mistake by the Department. The article continues:
The advice to Button said it was discovered when a local `beneficiary', Software Developments, did not benefit as much as expected.
The Minister's Department advised Senator Button. I now wish to quote from Mr Brammall's article in which he is quoting from these confidential papers:

`The issue is whether to make this adjustment public or not. The downgrading/mistake `could be hidden away in the aggregate figures for the nine reviews, but there would be severe embarrassment, particularly for the Government, if this matter was `discovered' at some later date.

`An alternative would be to name Cincom and put it in terms of an example of the verification process at work. But as Cincom are not at fault and this could reflect adversely on them, I do not favour either approach.

Rather, I believe we should, without naming Cincom, report that the latest export figures include a downward adjustment to take account of the results of the verification activities which revealed a misunderstanding of the basis on which reporting exports should be undertaken. Whilst this may attract media comment, it will be more manageable than a revelation at a late date.'

What an unbelievable indictment of this Minister who is so proud of his credibility. I have repeatedly pointed out that one has to be very cautious when listening to and reading the words of Senator Button because he is very articulate. He is clever in manipulating the English language. This is a perfect example of how it is possible for him to mislead this Parliament, journalists and the whole of the nation by cleverly making statements which on the surface appear to mean one thing yet, in truth, mean practically the opposite of what he is talking about. Senator Button has repeatedly claimed success for his industry policies. I have repeatedly pointed out that all Senator Button is doing in this country at present is propping up industry wherever he possibly can because the macro-economy and the micro-economy of this nation are poor. The economy is terrible; it is woeful. The only way that industry, especially industry dealing with what are called elaborately transformed manufacturers, can succeed in the current economic climate of Australia is by getting government hand-outs, by dipping its snout into the taxpayers' trough. Once again I ask Senator Button: How deep are the pockets of the taxpayers of Australia? How much more money is the Government going to take from the taxpayers of Australia in order to cling to government, which is what this is all about? This Government is desperately trying to cling to government in the face of an election to be held very soon at which the people of Australia will turn on this Government and savage it. The Government is prepared to spend as much of the taxpayers' money as it possibly can in an attempt to cling to government.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —I want to respond briefly to some of the remarks made by Senator Lewis. Anybody listening to what he had to say would have to conclude that he is saying only one thing: he has a problem because, as he put it, I am clever and he is not. I agree with that. I think he has a problem about that. I am not making an estimate of my own abilities; after hearing what he had to say, I am certainly making one of his.

speech.para: In the course of his remarks he accused me of a number of things. In doing so, he has walked into the political kitchen where the heat is. Senator Lewis accused me of a number of things which I want to deal with. Firstly, without prior warning that he was going to do so, he quoted from a journal, a copy of which he gave me one minute before he got to his feet. He referred to a journalist named Colin Brammall. The best that I can say about Colin Brammall is that he has a lot of problems; he is a very sad man. Senator Lewis cites Colin Brammell's report of alleged advice from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce about certain documents which were put to me. I have not seen that advice to which Senator Lewis refers. Senator Lewis always picks up scuttlebutt in the less reputable press and uses it as matters of fact in debate in this Parliament.

I want to remind Senator Lewis that when he talks about me propping up industry in Australia he should bear in mind that in the manufacturing industry in this country under this Government production levels have been higher than ever before. Profitability has been higher than ever before. Employment has been higher than ever before. If Senator Lewis wants to debate some of those fundamental facts, let him come in here and do it. As distinct from the Liberal Party period of government, we have reduced tariffs in this country since 1970 by 65 per cent. Not one percentage point of those reductions took place under Liberal governments; it all took place under Labor governments. He goes around attacking my personal credibility saying that it is based on my capacity to use words; nothing else.

Because it suited him, Senator Lewis said a little while ago that the Government was handing out $2.5 billion to industry. I suggest that he take that issue up with his friends in the National Party of Australia. What he was intending to imply in that statement was that that money was being handed out to manufacturing industry in this country; it is not. If Senator Lewis is saying that, it is a lie. He should look at the rural support schemes which are included in that $2.5 billion, the hand-outs to agriculture, and take them up with his friends in the National Party. It imposed massive burdens for years on the Australian taxpayer by prop-ups to rural industries. Some of those are still there.

talk.start.para: —What has that got to do with partnerships?

—Senator Bishop should mind her own business for the time being; I am dealing with Senator Lewis, and I will come to Senator Bishop in a minute. The next thing Senator Lewis went on to say in the course of this debate after accusing me of propping up industry, which is not supported by the facts at all in terms of production, in terms of employment and in terms of what has happened in manufacturing in this country, was that the Government offered a bribe to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, which is unlawful.
—That's right.

—Did Senator Lewis not listen to the answer which he got from Senator Walsh in Question Time today? It is not unlawful. Governments throughout the history of this country have had the power to legislate and override existing legislation, and they have done it. Senator Lewis characterises the action as unlawful, but Senator Lewis himself announced publicly a week or two ago, `We will oppose the legislation when it is introduced' and then he comes in here and says that the Government is acting unlawfully.
—Well, it is. You cannot guarantee the legislation.

—Of course not. That does not make it unlawful. I thought Senator Bishop had a bit of legal training. Senator Bishop ought to go back to her law books and have a look. To talk about an action like that as unlawful is a smear of the lowest possible character which one would expect in Richmond politics in Victoria but not here in Federal politics. It is a dreadful allegation to make, as is the allegation about bribes to Kodak and so on.

speech.para: Senator Lewis says that the Government has not been public about many of these issues. The Government has been more public about industry assistance issues than any other government in the history of this country, and particularly governments of the opposite political persuasion. To come in here and base one's argument on a headline which is picked out of a not too credible computer journal is reprehensible in the extreme. The article on the next page by the same journalist has the headline `DITAC shake-up likely over partners'. Is that right? Does Mr Brammall know that? I do not know that. How does Mr Brammall know that? He knows it because it is a figment of his imagination, as many of the other things which he writes are. It is a very unhealthy situation where nitwit journalists are supporting nitwit politicians and where there is a sort of daisy-chain of intellectual--

talk.start.para: —I have a point of order, Mr President. Here the Minister is attacking a journalist who is simply doing his job. The Minister does not like the message, so he seeks this cheap way of getting at him.
—There is no point of order.

—Of course there is no point of order. Senator Bishop would like to interrupt what I have to say because it is not particularly palatable to her. It is not particularly palatable to Senator Lewis. It is unfortunate that Senator Lewis has crept in here without notice in an adjournment debate on Estimates day and made these unsubstantiated allegations; it is pretty cowardly.
—Oh, come on!

—It amounts to the basic problem that ran right through Senator Lewis's speech. He is concerned about my credibility; he is concerned about lowering my credibility in the community. My credibility is a difficulty for him, and I understand that. He has a problem, but it is a problem which will not be resolved in the adjournment debate in the Senate.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: —I rise to touch briefly on the matter of the leave of absence sought for Senator Vallentine earlier in the adjournment debate. The chamber, when it granted leave to Senator Vallentine on the basis that she was unable to find a way to Canberra, should have understood that each State is represented by 12 senators and that 11 of these senators from Western Australia were able to find their way to the national capital to represent their constituents in the chamber to which they were elected; Senator Vallentine could not. Unless I am wrong, there is a Royal Australian Air Force VIP aircraft leaving Perth this morning flying directly to Canberra. Yet we have an application from Senator Vallentine for leave of absence because she is unable to find her way here. Whilst at the end of the day the record will show her as being absent, because she was granted leave of absence when she comes under attack, as no doubt she will, for her lack of performance, her lack of attendance, the lack of occasions on which she voted on divisions, her constituents will be misled into believing that the Senate has understood her reason for not being here and has granted her leave of absence. Let it be understood that this morning the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia both voted on the voices against the granting of leave. Senator Vallentine is not here now; she was not here yesterday; she was not here the day before.
—Because she is not interested in Senate estimates; that is the reason.

—Senator Michael Baume quite rightly points out that this week and next week the Senate is directing its attention to the very important and fundamental question of examining the estimates of the various Government departments and agencies. That matter does not particularly interest Senator Vallentine, so she has chosen not to come to parliament. What are school children doing who do not want to go to school?
—Wagging.
—She is wagging Parliament. She is having a nice week at home with dad and the kids.
—What, on 49 grand a year?

—Or something equally as modest! Everybody else is required to be here. Senator Vallentine is the only honourable senator in Australia who cannot get to the national capital to fulfil her obligations, notwithstanding the fact that the Government has gone to a great deal of trouble to facilitate travel to ensure that honourable senators and honourable members are able to be here to participate in the deliberation and consideration of and the voting on legislation.

speech.para: There ought to be a general rule of thumb. If leave is granted it ought to be on the basis of compassionate grounds so that the Senate can make a proper determination, parliamentary or electorate responsibilities, or perhaps private business-three simple and easily definable and understood reasons for being absent. But it should not be put in general terms. Is it not an irony that it was an Australian Democrat who applied for her leave of absence? It is lucky that one of them is here to seek leave.

talk.start.para: —It wasn't a Democrat.

—Yes it was. Senator Vallentine is not here because leave of absence was applied for by Senator Coulter on Tuesday. He sought leave on the basis that Senator Vallentine was not able to be here because of unavoidable business-whatever that might mean. We do not know whether it is electorate business, parliamentary business, private business, family business or what it is. The honourable senator is not here for this week of sittings because of business-some obscure reason! When her leave of absence expired, her excuse for not being here was that she could not get here. The reason she cannot get here is that she is not here. She should have been here, like everybody else, at the beginning of the week.

speech.para: From now on I intend to inquire as to the reasons independent senators who infrequently attend the chamber, who frequently do not vote in divisions, who frequently do not contribute to debates, deliberations and considerations, and who never participate in the vital role of the scrutiny of government by way of Estimates committees, seek leave of absence. If Senator Vallentine genuinely wanted to be here today, I have no doubt she could have been here by lunch time, because flights are available. We have heard only a phoney excuse.

question.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 7 June 1989:

question.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 17 July 1989:

question.para: What evidence does the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce have of reduced export performance and inhibited investment in new capacity plant and equipment as a result of the sustained higher value of the Australian dollar.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: I presume that the Question is largely related to the 1988 calendar year in which the nominal value of the Australian dollar (as measured by the Trade-weighted index) increased by about 25 per cent.
This increase was from an historically quite low level and, even at the end of 1988, the nominal value of the dollar was still considerably less than during the first half of the 1980s.

However, since February this year, the $A has depreciated against most major world currencies. The trade-weighted index (the most relevant measure of the value of $A) declined by 8 per cent over this period.
It is true that the rate of growth of exports slowed in 1988/89.

Although part of this slowdown could reflect a decline in the international competitiveness of Australian exporters due to the increased value of the $A, the more likely major factor restricting exports has been the recent surge in domestic demand which has reduced industries' capacity to service export markets.
But, despite the slowdown in export activity, exports still recorded a healthy growth in this year (about 5 per cent in real terms).

Of particular note has been the continued strong growth of manufactured exports, which picked up in the second half of 1988/89. For the June Quarter 1989, manufactured exports, in real terms, were 7 per cent greater than the corresponding period in the previous year.
As to the second part of the question, investment does not appear to have been significantly inhibited by the increase in the value of the $A that took place in 1988.
Indeed, there is some evidence to suggest that the increased value of the $A has stimulated investment by reducing the price of imported capital items.
The level of private investment increased strongly in both 1987/88 and 1988/89.
In 1988/89, total private investment increased by as much as 15 per cent in real terms.
This strong investment growth considerably exceeds the 7-8 per cent real growth in investment that occurred in the mid 1980s.
Whether an increase in the value of the $A has had a different effect on investment to expand capacity and investment for replacement purposes is not clear.
It is often claimed that a large part of recent investment activity has been to replace and update old equipment rather than for capacity expansion.
However, these results can be misleading as replacement investment can significantly increase our capacity to compete on world markets.

Investment to update old equipment is important in bringing Australia's existing products up to world standard, in removing bottlenecks in production (thereby augmenting existing production) and for installing more flexibility in the production process.

Dear Mr Hill,
I am writing to you to ask that you carry out, under provisions of section 63P of the Audit Act 1901, an inspection and audit of the accounts and records of the Central Land Council in Alice Springs.

Section 38 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs may at any time cause a person having the prescribed qualifications to inspect and audit the accounts and records of a Land Council. Land Councils are provided with funds for their administrative expenses from the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA) established by the Act. Because royalty equivalent payments into the ABTA are insufficient, supplementation of Council funds has been made by way of advances from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The situation of the Council's finances were drawn to the attention of the Council by their auditors, Messrs Wallace McMullin and Smail, who have been conducting a special audit at the Council's request. I have written to the Land Council suggesting that the accounting and payments function of the Council be returned to a firm of public accountants and that a Management Consultant will be engaged to examine all aspects of the Council's functions and operations and advise on appropriate changes.

I would envisage the audit I am now requesting, as including a report on the Council's compliance with the requirements of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and on any operational deficiencies which may be found. It is for this reason that I believe an independent audit of the Council would be useful.
