Dear Mr Scrutton

Your telex to me on December 23, 1980, sought approval to overdraft facilities being provided for your Council. Subsequent discussions between officers of my Department and Mr Ormrod disclosed the fact that Council was in overdraft to the extent of $68,000, with the prospect of that amount increasing until further funds become available to the Council.
With your agreement and Mr Ormrod's two of my officers visited the Council and held discussions on the financial difficulties being experienced.
At the same time, Council auditors, Wallace McMullin and Smail, were conducting an audit at Mr Ormrod's request because of his concern that there may have been irregularity with Council accounts.

The results of both those inquiries have been disturbing. Mr Ormrod informed me that as a result the audit police have been brought in to investigate an apparent misappropriation of some $70,000-$80,000 and that charges will probably be laid.

The inquiries made by my officers, which had co-operation of your Council staff and of your auditors, have indicated some serious problems in the control of Council finances, some of which would have created the opportunity for funds to be misappropriated or misused.
I do not wish in this letter to go into detail, but the following are matters of serious concern:
the practice of one signature only being required on Council cheques
the lack of separation of responsibilities of certain administrative staff who are able to authorise payments as well as make them by way of cheque or cash
the ordering of services or goods without recourse to the proper procedures of formal purchase orders and checking as to funds availability and reasonableness of purchase of the service or goods
the payment by Council in the past of personal debts of employees and subsequent recoupment from their salaries
inadequate control over purchase of vehicle spares, tyres, toolkits and so on with the result that many of these are unable to be accounted for

the creation of new staff positions by Council without prior approval by the Public Service Board of terms and conditions, or of myself for additions to Council estimates of expenditure to fund those positions
the retention on staff of persons who appear to lack the ability or willingness to perform their work at the level expected of them.

Money used by Land Councils derive from the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account under sub-section 64 (1) of the Land Rights Act. Until royalty income into the ABTA is sufficiently high to enable the total of Land Council approved budgets to be met from that source, supplementation is required from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, or the general funds of the ABTA, under sub-section 64 (7) of the Act.

Money advanced to Land Council from the Consolidated Revenue Fund will need to be repaid from the ABTA; they are not a grant to Councils. Moneys in the ABTA apart from the essential expenses of the Councils provided for under sub-section 64 (1) are for the benefit of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. Excessive expenditure by Councils reduces the availability of funds for these people.

Section 34 of the Act provides for me to approve Land Council estimates of expenditure, and it is my duty to ensure that the budgets are responsible ones. Section 37 requires that a Council exercise proper controls over its moneys and assets. Taking all of these things into account, I would be failing in my responsibilities if I did not take immediate and effective action to rectify the situation in which the Central Land Council is now placed.

Section 38 (2) of the Act empowers me to order an inspection and audit of the accounts and records of Council. I intend to invoke this power and will shortly inform you of the name of the auditor appointed.
I consider that other urgent corrective actions should be immediately instituted along the lines of the following:
Council Finances-for the time being, the financial operations of the Council should be placed in the hands of a public accountant, as was the previous practice

CLC Structure and Organisation-a Management Consultant should be engaged to examine all aspects of Council functions and operations and to advise on appropriate changes of staffing structure and organisation and the securing of appropriate staff as well as appropriate methods of control of finances and assets. I would hope that the effect of these moves will be the setting up of a strong and appropriate Land Council staff able to cope with the heavy workload with which the Council will be faced in the next few years.

Concerning the loss of moneys and any over-expenditure of items within the budget, I must advise you that I expect the Council to adjust its budget to live within the overall amount approved for 1980-81 without any carry-forward into 1981-1982 of excessive financial commitments. It will also be necessary for the Council to eliminate its overdraft at the earliest opportunity. I cannot give any commitment that additional finance will be available to meet deficits resulting from the Council's mismanagement of its affairs.

I understand that Mr Bill Gay is to meet with you in the week commencing February 2 and I have asked him to discuss with you and your officers the implementation of these and any other urgent corrective measures which might be appropriate.

It is unfortunate that these problems should have come to a head at the beginning of your term as Chairman but I hope you will agree with my own view that it is an opportunity for the Council to make a fresh start and hopefully to emerge as a stronger organisation able to cope successfully with the very demanding role expected of it.

question.para: (1) When will the feasibility study for the Multifunction Polis (MFP) project being funded by Australian State and Federal Governments, the Japanese Government and the Australian and Japanese corporations be completed.
(2) What is the current status of the actual concept, that is, what will the MFP comprise.
(3) Will the MFP evolve into a new city, a precinct or a single centre at the end of an established city.

(4) With regard to a report in Australian Business on 21 June 1989, that if a specific location is not soon identified then the whole project will wither on the vine, when will a site be named by the Government.

(5) The `Australian Business' article on 21 June also states that the aim of the MFP was to become `the world's environment management centre'-is this one of the aims of the MFP: if so, when was it incorporated among the aims and at whose instigation.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The feasibility study is scheduled for completion on 31 March 1990 when a report from the MFP Joint Steering Committee will be submitted to the Australian and Japanese Governments. The consultancy study currently being undertaken by the Arthur Andersen/Kinhill Group will be completed on 22 December 1989.

(2) An `MFP concept' has been developed which encapsulates a number of themes and business areas consistent with the objectives of Australia and Japan. In brief, the concept involves a modern, high quality, urban environment incorporating state-of-the-art infrastructure. This would be linked to a number of core industries where Australia is likely to be internationally competitive in the latter 1990s and the 21st century. The sectors which are likely to form the core of an MFP include education, information and telecommunications, health, environment and agriculture, construction and design, and advanced transport services.

The concept is being further refined through a program of market testing, an examination of spatial and site considerations, and by studies of the commercial viability of identified industry opportunities. Potential investors will be canvassed on the factors considered essential to make the MFP an attractive investment proposition.

(3) The MFP Joint Secretariat is currently considering draft proposals from interested State and Territory Governments which relate the likely locational requirements of an MFP to specific regions throughout Australia. At present, the spatial form of the MFP has not been limited beyond the following possibilities:
(a) a single `core' site within a major metropolitan region complemented by one or more specialised, satellite centres located elsewhere in Australia;
(b) multiple sites in a single major metropolitan region; or

(c) single sites spread either across two or three separate major metropolitan regions or, alternatively, within one medium-sized, urban region (eg. Adelaide, Perth/Fremantle, Canberra/Goulburn, or Brisbane/Gold Coast).
By 31 October 1989, specific physical configurations and potential sites for the MFP will have been identified, considered and ranked.

(4) A site (or sites) for the MFP cannot be named before the feasibility study is completed and the Governments of Australia and Japan receive the Joint Steering Committee's report. In that report, site proposals will be ranked according to their specific spatial and site characteristics.

The MFP feasibility study is a joint project between Australia and Japan, and has been funded by the private and public sectors in both countries. All parties involved in the project have agreed to the work program which is currently being pursued and fully support its completion by 31 March 1990.

(5) The environmental theme contained in the draft MFP concept is one of a number of areas of potential commercial opportunity identified by the feasibility study consultant. This is supported by analysis undertaken by a series of `think-tanks' convened by MFP Australia Research Ltd, the company through which the Australian business community is contributing to the MFP feasibility study. More generally, the Australian and Japanese Domestic Committees agreed in May this year that environmental management should be a central aspect of the MFP project. If pursued, the MFP's environmental focus could demonstrate the type of environmental safeguards appropriate to forms of urban development in the 21st century.

answer.to.qon.title: Parliament House Construction Workers: Compensation for Injuries

question.speaker: Sanders Sen N.K.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 August 1989:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that Messrs Hans Schmidt, a form work contractor involved in the construction of Parliament House became bankrupt in 1986.
(2) Is it a fact that a number of employees of Hans Schmidt were at the time receiving workers' compensation, payments for work-related injury.
(3) How many such workers were there at the time.
(4) What is the legal obligation of the insurer (in this case, FAI) of a bankrupted firm to continue compensation payments to injured workers.
(5) Is it a fact that payments to injured Hans Schmidt employees have been made by the Parliament House Construction Authority.
(6) What steps has the Minister taken, or will the Minister take, to recover compensation money paid by the PHCA, from the insurer.

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Hans Schmidt and Partners (ACT) Pty Limited became bankrupt during 1986.
(2) Yes.

(4) The issue is the subject of legal actions through the courts, the first of which is currently being heard by Mr Justice Wilcox in the ACT Supreme Court. The outcome of this action should determine the legal obligation of the insurer in respect of compensation payments to one (1) of the former employees of Hans Schmidt and Partners (ACT) Pty Limited (Hans Schmidt). It should also be indicative of the insurer's obligation to the other five (5) former employees.
(5) Yes.

(6) In March 1987 Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) obtained an undertaking from each of the six (6) former employees of Hans Schmidt who were in receipt of payments from the Authority. This undertaking required each of the six (6) to institute a claim for compensation under the Workers' Compensation Ordinance 1951 (as amended) against Hans Schmidt. In the event of the satisfaction of such claims and the successful recovery of compensation, the undertaking obliges each of the six to reimburse PHCA the full amount paid by way of compensation. In conjunction with the Australian Government Solicitor all legal means available will be used to recover moneys paid out by PHCA in this matter.

question.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1989:

question.para: Has the Minister been made aware of the dispute between his department and the Kalkadoon Tribal Council relating to the conduct of the AOT Training program in the Boulia, Dajarra, Urandangie and Southern regions; if so, has he investigated the allegations of threats from his departmental officers to Tribal Council workers, if not, why not, if so, what are the results of the investigations.

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I have been advised that there has been a misunderstanding between Mr James Taylor and officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in relation to funding arrangements for certain aspects of the AOT Training program.

I have received a report on the allegations by Mr Taylor that he was threatened. I am satisfied that no serious threat was ever made against Mr Taylor or any other Tribal Council worker but Mr Taylor may have misinterpreted some remark made during a meeting on 21 July 1989 called to resolve misunderstandings on the role that the Tribal Council was to play in the AOT Training program.

question.speaker: Vanstone Sen A.E.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 30 August 1989:

question.para: (1) Has the Prime Minister ever informed his Ministers that they and their staff are not required to keep records of any conversations they may have with media representatives.

(2) Does the Prime Minister consider that a practice or convention is in existence to the effect that Ministers and their staff are not required to keep records of any conversations they may have with media representatives.

(3) Does the Prime Minister consider a precedent would be established if any of his Ministers were to confirm or deny that he or she had had a conversation with a media representative, what the substance of that conversation was and when it took place.
(4) On what occasions has the Prime Minister been asked to state whether he has had a conversation with a media representative and has answered the question.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (4) It is difficult to determine precisely the implied propositions and nature of the information sought by the honourable senator. It is not possible, therefore, to respond in any detailed or comprehensive way. I can inform the honourable senator, however, that I have not instructed Ministers along the lines I understand her to suggest.
